context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: And just as in Bell Atlantic--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Okay.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I -- I think you are right that if somebody makes just a totally bizarre allegation that nobody in the world could take seriously, that -- that the issue can be raised.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But in Justice Breyer's case, the -- that -- that may be the case if the claim is that the president of Coke was -- was personally putting mouses in bottles.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But the claim, it seems to me, that the Attorney General or the Director of the FBI was establishing a policy of no release until cleared or a policy that centered on people with the same characteristics as the hijackers does not have that kind of bizarre character to it and, I think, would not run afoul of the -- of the plausibility standard.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: --Well, we certainly think -- I mean, in Bell Atlantic, the Court said common economic experience would -- would support its determination in that case.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: We don't think the Court should do that.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: When the Court dispensed -- disavowed the broad no-set-of-facts language from Conley v. Gibson, we took the Court to be saying: We are disavowing that for all cases under Rule 8; we are not limiting it to parallel conduct in the section 1 of the Sherman Act context.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre
context.text: So I think that Bell Atlantic's explication of Rule 8 and the disavowal of the no-set-of-facts language, which, after all, is the test under which the district court had to resort to, to sustain the claims in this case--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It's hard for me to believe we had to wait for Twombly in order to have this, and it seems to me Rule 11 is not applicable here because it simply works after the fact.

context.speaker: Gregory G. Garre

context.speaker: Alexander A. Reinert
context.text: Now, Bell Atlantic doesn't -- doesn't prohibit plaintiffs from pleading cases in the alternative.

context.speaker: Alexander A. Reinert
context.text: And if you are going to plead cases in the alternative, it's possible, of course, that some people will ultimately be held responsible and some won't.

context.speaker: Alexander A. Reinert
context.text: But the--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Do you agree that -- to follow up on Justice Breyer's questioning of General Garre, do you believe that the same pleading standards apply in the action against the president of Coca-Cola as apply to the actions of the Attorney General and Director of the FBI on the evening of September 11, 2001?

context.speaker: Alexander A. Reinert

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I'm sorry?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: [Laughter]

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You can let me know.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I -- I'm starting with the assumption, which I think is -- is in Bell Atlantic, that what we are concerned with in context is that the -- the context tells us how specific you've got to be versus how conclusory you've got to be, and the reason it does so is that some allegations are -- are more likely to be true than others depending on the context.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Is it fair to say -- going back to Justice Breyer's question, is it fair to say that your basic pleading here rests on the following assumption: That it is more plausible that the Attorney General of the United States and the Director of the FBI were in fact directly involved in devising a policy with the racial characteristics and the coercive characteristics that you claim, than that the President of Coca Cola was putting mouses in bottles?

context.speaker: Alexander A. Reinert
context.text: --Well, I think that -- I think that is our -- our contention, Your Honor, because it's a -- it's an allegation about a policy.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: So you would say, if -- to the Coke question you would say, yes, they've got to get more facts there, this is just -- this is just crazy to think that the president is putting mice in the bottles.

context.speaker: Alexander A. Reinert
context.text: We certainly don't think it's absurd or bizarre, which is the argument that the Petitioners raised below--

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: But that's also not the--

context.speaker: Alexander A. Reinert
context.text: --I'm sorry.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: --Absurd and bizarre is also not the pleading standard, and how are we -- to follow up on Justice Souter's question -- how are we supposed to judge whether we think it's more unlikely that the president of Coca-Cola would take certain actions as opposed to the Attorney General of the United States?

context.speaker: Alexander A. Reinert
context.text: I think it is a problem posed by that interpretation of Bell Atlantic.

context.speaker: Alexander A. Reinert
context.text: I don't think it's a problem that's posed by this particular case, Mr. Chief Justice.

context.speaker: Alexander A. Reinert
context.text: And that, we think, is another way of resolving the case.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --May I ask you this question?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And -- and I ask it, you know, mindful of what you've just said, but I -- I'm not sure that the two issues can be kept as -- as separated as you suggest.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Another avenue to responding to the problem, I think, that Justice Breyer's last hypo raised would be as follows -- and then I'll tell you the difficulty that I have with it, and I was going ask you to comment on the difficulty.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: He said that the -- the allegation -- one way to read the allegation, and I think a fair way, is to say that the Attorney General and the Director of the FBI devised a policy and condoned the implementation of a policy that was based on racial and religious grounds with no penological purpose.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, under the circumstances of immediate post-9/11, it is not surprising necessarily that they -- they devised a policy that had reference to religion and national origin and so on, given what we knew about the hijackers.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, under the circumstances of immediate post-9/11, it is not surprising necessarily that they -- they devised a policy that had reference to religion and national origin and so on, given what we knew about the hijackers.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: What is not so easy to accept, as a matter of adequate pleading, is the claim that there was no penological interest involved in the decision of how to and how long to hold the individuals who were picked up.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: One answer to that, which I think is -- is in your pleadings, is that you refer to specific individuals and in particular to your own client, who was in the position of being held under these conditions for a considerable period of time, and it turns out there's -- there's no indication that there was ultimately a justified penological interest.

context.speaker: David H. Souter

context.speaker: David H. Souter

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: As one of the joint authors of the opinion in McConnell, I must emphatically disagree with today's all changing decision.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: When Justice O'Connor and I were working on our opinion in that case, we thought that two important propositions of law were so well settled that they needed no special defense.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The first, that Congress may place special restrictions on the use of corporate funds in election campaigns, had been generally recognized for a century or more.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In the second, that there is a relevant distinction between a corporate speech about general issues on the one hand and corporate speech specifically advocating the election or defeat of a candidate on the other, was not only established by our earlier cases but had also helped shape the extensive debates in Congress that led to the enactment of the statute.

Citizens United v. Federal Election Comm.speaker: Justice Stevens
Citizens United v. Federal Election Comm.case_name: Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission
Citizens United v. Federal Election Comm.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 21, 2010

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It had specifically limited the independent expenditures of corporations on candidate elections ever since the Taft-Hartley Act of 1947.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Many states have had similar laws on the books for a comparable period of time, if not longer.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Before today, no Court opinion, not one had ever questioned the validity of these laws.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: To the contrary, as Justice Rehnquist wrote for a unanimous Court in 1982, we have consistently ruled and I am quoting that, "Congress careful legislative adjustment of the federal electoral laws in -- in a cautious advantage, advanced step-by-step to count for the particular legal and economic attributes of corporations, warrants considerable deference and that it reflects a permissible assessment of the dangers imposed by those entities to the electoral process."

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We have unanimously concluded that these laws and again I am quoting, "Reflect a permissible assumption of the dangers inpro -- imposed by corporations to the electoral process and we have accept -- accepted the legislative judgment that the special characteristics of the corporate structure require particularly careful regulation.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In a long line of cases, we have likewise concluded that the ability to form political action committees reflects -- provides corporations with a constitutionally sufficient opportunity to finance electioneering, at the same time that it protects the interest of dissenting shareholders.

Citizens United v. Federal Election Comm.speaker: Justice Stevens
Citizens United v. Federal Election Comm.case_name: Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission
Citizens United v. Federal Election Comm.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JANUARY 21, 2010

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Nothing has changed since 1920 that justifies a reexamination of those conclusions.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The majority rests virtually its entire doctrinal argument on two cases: Buckley against Valeo decided in 1974 and First National Bank of Boston against Bellotti decided in 1988 -- 1978.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In 1975, the cor -- the bar on corporate contributions and expenditures had become such an accepted part of campaign finance regulation that when a large number of corporations challenged virtually every aspect of the 1971 Federal Campaign Act in Buckley, no one even bothered to argue that the bar as such was unconstitutional.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: And in 1970 when the Court decided Bellotti, no member of the Court disagreed with the express statement in Justice Powell's majority opinion that our holding on corporations' right to speak on issues of general interest implied no comparable right in the quite different context of candidate elections.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In light of this history, it is clear that Austin was well supported by our earlier cases.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The only novel development in Austin were the sleeping -- sweeping attacks on the State of Michigan's corporate expenditure, restriction and dissents filed by Justices Scalia and Thomas.

Citizens United v. Federal Election Comm.speaker: Justice Stevens

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The Court's fourth error is its assumption that there is only one governmental interest that counts in the area of campaign finance, so called quid pro quo corruption and appearance of such corruption.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: In my judgment, this crabbed approach disregards our constitutional history in the functional demands of a democratic society.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: On numerous occasions, we have recognized Congress' legitimate interest in preventing the money that is spent on elections from exerting undue influence on an officeholder's judgment and creating the appearance of such influence beyond this sphere of quid quo pro relationships.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Corporruption can take many forms, but as Justice Souter has explained in more than one opinion, the difference in selling a vote and selling access is a matter of degree not kind, and selling access is not qualitatively different from giving special preference to those who spent money on one's behalf.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Corruption operates along a spectrum and the majority's apparent belief that quid pro quo arrangements can be neatly be demarcated from other improper influence, does not accord with the -- the theory or reality of politics.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: It certainty does not accord with the record Congress developed in passing BCRA, a record that contained detailed findings about the corrupting consequences of corporate and union independent expenditures in the years preceding the law's passage and which amply supported Congress' determination that the basic integrity of our political system as well as the public's faith in that system was in jeopardy.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The Court's First Amendment analysis is based on the metaphor of an open parket -- marketplace of ideas, but the Court never actually engages with the reality of how that marketplace operates or indeed with virtually any practical concerns, whatever.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The Court's decision is at war with the views of generations of Americans who have worked to improve our campaign spends -- campaign finance system and thus to safeguard the integrity of the electoral process with the views of many of the state legislatures that over many decades have enacted laws similar to the Michigan statute we upheld in Austin with the views of the Congress that enacted the Tillman Act in 1907, the Congress that enacted the -- Taft-Hartley Act in 1947, the Congress that enacted the Federal Electorate Campaign Act in 1971 and the Congress that enacted the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act of 2002 and with the views expressed by the overwhelming majority of Justices who served on this Court.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The majority's rejection of the long standing consents -- consensus on the need to limit corporate spending -- spend -- corporate campaign spending,

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: in words Justice White once used, elevates corporations to eleven of -- level of deference which has not been seen at least since the days when substantive due process was regularly used to invalidate regular -- regulatory legislation thought to unfairly impinge upon established economic interests.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: At bottom, the Court's opinion is just a rejec-- rejection of the common sense of the American people as expressed in 1907 in the Senate Report on the Tillman Act which observed that the evils of the use of corporate money in connection within political elections are so generally recognized that the committee be -- deems it unnecessary to make any argument in favor of the general purpose of this measure.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: What was common sates -- sense in 1907 remains common sense for -- common sense today.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: The Second Circuit recognized that latter kind of taking account of costs disproportionate, more than the industry would bear, and they also recognized a cost comparison.

context.text: If you have a cheaper method that is almost as good, you can use that and you don't have to use the one that will capture the extra fish.

context.text: Well, first off -- I'm sorry.

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: I guess one basic point is just that this -- first off -- excuse me.

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: --Not -- well -- but with costbenefit analyses, again, this is -- this is routinely done by agencies.

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: The -- the statisticians and the economists--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It is -- let me -- I will -- I will grant you that agencies purport to do this kind of thing.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But my question and I think Justice Ginsburg's question is, does it make any sense in these circumstances to think that you really can do a cost-benefit analysis?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And if the answer is no -- we have been purporting to do it but it really doesn't make a lot of sense -- then it either means that there is just going to be an irrational process going on, or it means that the technology-driven standard basically is going to be read right out of the statute, because you are always going to find some disproportion which is -- which is going to limit your use of technology.

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: --No, the -- I think the most irrational thing would be to just throw up one's hands and say that we are going to impose standards whether or not they do more harm than good, whether or not they make any sense.

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: These -- well, all of these words can have different meanings.

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: I think of the four best technology provisions that are expressly cross-referenced in this provision, the one that's most informative here is the best conventional pollutant control technology, because Congress expressly required cost-benefit consideration in determining the best conventional pollutant control technology.

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: And "best" is the only word in that phrase that is amenable to a cost-benefit reading.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, my -- I think maybe what Justice Ginsburg was beginning to get at is my question here.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I assume that BTA is the most rigorous of the standards set forth in the statute.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: You can argue with that assumption, but then grant me the assumption for the moment.

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: I mean especially -- Congress enacted all of these provisions in 1972, and it provided at that time that in determining pollution discharge, even including toxic pollution discharge, EPA was required to consider the relationship between cost and benefits up until 1989.

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: And it makes no sense to think that Congress would have wanted stricter standards for fish here than for people under the toxic discharge provisions.

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: And on its face--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Are you disagreeing with the premise of Justice Kennedy's question?

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: --Yes.

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: Our argument is that--

context.speaker: Richard J. Lazarus
context.text: I think the real reason in 1972 was that Congress saw what happened before, and they said, it turns out to be really hard in the water quality context to measure and value environmental impact.

context.speaker: Richard J. Lazarus
context.text: It's so hard that we think that EPA can get a better, more rational result if we instead say, here's what you focus on, technology available, minimizing, and don't try to compare.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --But I think -- I see your point, but I think if I accept your point, all I am doing is saying, they may in a kind of smoke and mirrors way take cost-benefit analysis into consideration sub rosa, when they decide what availability is going to mean; and they make take it into consideration when they decide what a -- a -- an undesirable environmental impact is; and that sort of gets the -- the weighing process out of the public focus.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And if they do it that way, they -- they can bring in just the considerations that Justice Breyer is talking about, but they don't do it in an obvious way.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And I think that's what your argument boils down to.

context.speaker: Richard J. Lazarus

context.text: The question is, what do we do in an automatic appointment situation?

context.speaker: Donald B. Verrilli, Jr.
context.text: And this is a significant question because -- and I would refer the Court to the appendix, to the amicus brief of the National Legal Aid and Defender Association, which I think is a helpful reference here.

context.speaker: Donald B. Verrilli, Jr.
context.text: It goes through each State, and what it shows is that approximately half the States have procedures in which, as a matter of course, the defendant is asked at the hearing whether he or she wants counsel, and if the defendant says yes, then we're in a Jackson situation.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I just want to make sure I understood your answer to Justice Ginsburg's question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Assume a lawyer is appointed.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The defendant says,

context.speaker: Donald B. Verrilli, Jr.
context.text: Nobody has even argued that.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, Mr. Verrilli, you have spoken of -- of overruling a bright line, but I think there is something else that would be involved in the overruling.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And I -- I haven't pulled Jackson back out since I came on the bench, so this is where you've got to help me out.

context.speaker: David H. Souter

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You have phrased it in your argument in terms of saying a right to rely upon counsel, which is a much broader concept.

context.speaker: David H. Souter

context.speaker: David H. Souter

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.

context.speaker: Donald B. Verrilli, Jr.
context.text: --No, you have -- what you have is a right to rely on the assistance of your lawyer, and you have -- and -- and it's critical.

context.speaker: Donald B. Verrilli, Jr.
context.text: A good example of why it's critical--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Does the routine require the judge to tell him, you have got a lawyer, but he's not going to be available unless you say you want him?

context.speaker: Kathryn W. Landry
context.text: --No, because I think subsequently if he doesn't say anything when the police approach him, they tell him he has the right to counsel, and at that point he can exercise that right and say, I want a lawyer, I don't want to talk to you without a lawyer.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Ms. Landry, I don't really understand what you're arguing here.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I thought you were saying there has to be a request in your response to Justice Souter, but then you accept as sufficient his merely saying thank you.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: That's not a request.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

context.speaker: Kathryn W. Landry
context.text: --Because, in our case and in the case where there's just counsel appointed, again I go back to the issue, there's no request; there's no positive action by the defendant constituting a request in indicating that he's requesting a lawyer, which was the basis of the ruling in Jackson.

context.speaker: Kathryn W. Landry
context.text: It was -- and Patterson later said, Jackson turned on the fact that that defendant had asked for a lawyer.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Well, isn't the prophylactic aspect of Jackson not what Justice Breyer just said, but the rule that a person who has a lawyer is thereafter incapable of waiving the assistance of the lawyer if the person wishes to speak with the police and the police happen to initiate the conversation?

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.

context.speaker: Kathryn W. Landry

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.

context.speaker: Kathryn W. Landry

context.speaker: Kathryn W. Landry

context.speaker: Kathryn W. Landry

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer

context.text: I think this is very interesting to me because I'm learning a lot.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Suppose -- Let's assume Justice Alito is absolutely right and that when you have a counsel, that's what you've done and that's the reason why you don't talk to the police, or at least they can't initiate.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Fine.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: There's an irony in this case that Justice Kennedy put a finger on earlier: If there were a civil case, whether you could go talk to a lawyer -- a client, rather, who was represented by a lawyer, the answer would be quite clear: You could not, as a matter of professional ethics.

context.speaker: Kathryn W. Landry

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens

context.speaker: David H. Souter

context.text: But once again, he is a government actor.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But you -- you certainly cannot argue -- maybe you are, but I don't see how can you argue in response to Justice Ginsburg that the integrity to be expected from a confidential informant, taking that as a category of law including all sorts of informants, is the integrity that we would expect in a police officer.

context.speaker: Peter Stirba
context.text: --Well, as a general proposition, Justice Souter, you can't make that kind of determination.

context.speaker: Peter Stirba
context.text: We point out--

context.speaker: Peter Stirba
context.text: I don't think we should fault the police for essentially being careful before they entered the home to make sure that in fact they had probable cause.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The reason the police are being faulted is that they didn't get a warrant.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And the warrant requirement is a generally good starting place for a Fourth Amendment argument.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Justice Ginsburg's point is that if they had an informant who had seen drugs in the place within two hours, they had, if they'd been before a magistrate, the basis in probable cause to get a warrant.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And I still haven't heard why in fact they couldn't have got one or why they didn't have the probable cause.

context.speaker: Peter Stirba
context.text: Well, as I -- as I explained before, they believed the drugs in--

context.text: They clearly would have been if they had sent a police officer in.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You're asking us to extend the police officer rule to include a confidential informant rule.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: One reason for doing so is, or would be, that in practical terms there is a need for it.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Justice Ginsburg's question was, why is there a need for it, when they could have gotten a warrant?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And we still haven't heard an answer.

context.text: In rural Utah -- and this is page 47 of the joint appendix -- the officers testified that one of the reasons why they need to use confidential informants is because the police are all known.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But if our question is should consent once removed be recognized as a doctrine that covers the confidential informant in this case, one question that we may sensibly ask is, is there a need to recognize that broad a consent doctrine?

context.text: At the point at which the police officer who has been admitted has the knowledge necessary for an arrest and has that knowledge as a result of the invitation and the waiver of privacy as to him, why don't we regard that on sort of general doctrinal grounds as a waiver of privacy with respect to the police in general, just as we regard police knowledge as being imputed to all police officers?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: That way you don't have the problem that, for example, Justice Kennedy's hypo raises, even in the case of exigent circumstances.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But it doesn't open the door to what you were objecting to here.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Why isn't that a proper solution or proper answer to this hypo?

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Alito has the opinions of the Court in two cases this morning.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: The first case is Pearson versus Callahan 07-751.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: This case comes to us under the certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit.

context.speaker: Jay Alan Sekulow
context.text: And the fact is the Statue of Liberty originated by the Franco-American Union -- was originated by a third party.

context.speaker: Jay Alan Sekulow
context.text: The United States by resolution accepted it.

context.speaker: Jay Alan Sekulow
context.text: At that point title transfer.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: If that -- if we accept that there is Government speech, I think Justice Souter's question is isn't this really the Government endorsement of the Eagles' message?

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: I mean, the Eagles are all over this monument, their symbol of the eagle, and the Eagles want it to be known that this is their monument.

context.speaker: Ruth Bader Ginsburg
context.text: Indeed, I think in Van Orden wasn't the -- in the district court there, wasn't the statement, well, this -- Texas did this in recognition of the good work that the Eagles do in preventing -- help try to prevent juvenile delinquency.

context.speaker: Jay Alan Sekulow
context.text: I think that's important to point out.

context.speaker: Jay Alan Sekulow
context.text: The basis upon which they sought access, in you will, is a species of an equal access claim.

context.speaker: Jay Alan Sekulow
context.text: But of course our position is the Government hasn't established anything by accepting the monument.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: --But, Justice Stevens's question is important, maybe not for your case but for other cases.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: We are deciding this for other cases to arise, and why isn't he correct that if you don't like the message then that raises a content-based claim?

context.speaker: Jay Alan Sekulow
context.text: Because if the Government is speaking, if it's the Government's message, they're of course allowed to engage in content-based statements.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Even if it's a Government forum for private speech, I think it's the same thing.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: You're defining -- you define the forum to include only those -- the forum is putting up monuments.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: You just put up those monuments that agree with the message.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And the same question Justice Stevens had, just to tack onto his question here, your answer was: Oh, well, the Government owns it.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Suppose the Government says: We will accept ownership only if we agree with the message.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That just puts his question.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: That is control with a vengeance.

context.speaker: Jay Alan Sekulow
context.text: --The difference is -- the difference between each of those cases and the case here is the Fraternal Order of Eagles surrendered control of their message and their speech.

context.speaker: Jay Alan Sekulow
context.text: In the typical equal access case, Justice Stevens, they do not.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Well, they -- they do in the example Justice Kennedy just raised and the example that I just raised.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The Eagles come along say: Here's the monument; take it; it's all yours.

context.speaker: Jay Alan Sekulow
context.text: Which happened here.

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: But there are also -- there are two legal theories here.

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: The first is that this is Government speech.

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: The second is that this -- even if it was private speech, this would be one of those unusual contexts like public broadcasting, museums, libraries, where normal forum principles do not apply because the Government is acting as a curator and value judgments are, therefore, both inevitable and appropriate.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: What's the answer to Justice Alito's question?

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: I mean, if we wanted--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Well, supposing the Government in the Vietnam Memorial decided not to put up the names of any homosexual soldiers.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: I know how you're going to answer that question.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: You're going to say: Of course, it is.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But what's interesting me is, are we bound in these cases to apply what I think of as an artificial kind of conceptual framework or are we free to ask what seems to me to be at the heart of the matter?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The answer to Justice Stevens's hypothetically is: Of course the Government can't do that because it's disproportionate.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: I didn't get the answer.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Did you--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Did you--

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: --Yes, the Government can choose to memorialize who it wants on the mall.

context.speaker: Daryl Joseffer
context.text: When the Government is -- now, to be clear, that's under the Free Speech Clause.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: So what is the answer to the -- what is the answer to Justice Stevens's hypothetical?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What is the answer to the homosexual hypothetical?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: What is the answer?

context.speaker: Pamela Harris
context.text: But if the Government allows it all--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Those are time, place, and manner regulations, with which we are all familiar.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But my concern is that this -- this case is an example of the tyrannies -- of the tyranny of labels.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Because it's a public forum, as Justice Scalia indicated, for parades, for protests, which are limited temporally, it -- it -- it just seems wooden and rigid to say to all of a sudden say, well, it's a public forum for something that will last 30 years for which there is only limited space.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: It just doesn't make common sense.

context.speaker: Pamela Harris
context.text: --And that is exactly why, Justice Kennedy, the city, any city, is permitted to make a decision that it will close its public parks to all unattended displays.

context.speaker: Pamela Harris
context.text: So you can put yours up, and you can't.

context.speaker: Pamela Harris
context.text: That doesn't solve the First Amendment problem.

context.speaker: Pamela Harris
context.text: That is the First Amendment problem that the Government--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It may create the First Amendment problem, but it seems to me, going back to Justice Alito's question, that the City's decision is a clear adoption of the monument.

context.speaker: Pamela Harris
context.text: --If all we have, I think, Justice Souter, is that the city has permitted one private speaker to erect a monument, there is no constitutional or judicially manageable line between that and just the ordinary thing the Government always does when it grants preferred access to a public forum, which is to say you're in, you're out.

context.speaker: Pamela Harris
context.text: If that's enough for adoption, then there are no more First Amendment violations through lack of equal access.

context.speaker: Pamela Harris
context.text: And when the Government is speaking, as the United States, said it is entitled to make content and viewpoint distinctions, but in order to do that, it has to step up and speak itself.

context.speaker: Pamela Harris
context.text: That's the justification for the Government speech doctrine.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You're basically just arguing for a clear statement rule.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I mean, Justice Alito's question, my analogies are suggestive of the fact that there is an affirmative Government act of some indication of approval when it says, yes, you can put the monument here.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And what you're arguing for is, well, we want a clearer statement, we want it to say, yes, we really adopt it, it's ours from the heart.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And that seems to be the difference between your position and the -- and the position that acceptance of the monument is enough.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But it's not disclaiming it here.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The Government isn't disclaiming it.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And the difference it seems to me between you and your friends on the other side is you want this clear statement.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: You want a statement -- for example if you took Justice Scalia's statement, that would satisfy you, and it would also be the poison pill in the Establishment Clause.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Isn't that what's -- I mean, that's okay with me.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I don't see that as an illegitimate object.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Alito has our opinion this morning in case 07-665, Pleasant Grove City versus Summum.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: This case comes to us on writ of certiorari from the Tenth Circuit.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: Petitioner, Pleasant Grove City, owns and displays a number of monuments and other objects in Pioneer Park, Utah including a Ten Commandments monument.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: We conclude that although a park is a traditional public forum for speeches and other transitory expressive acts, the display of a permanent monument in a public park is not a form of expression to which form analysis supplies, instead, the placement of a permanent monument in a public park is best viewed as a form of government speech and is therefore not subject to scrutiny under the Free Speech Clause.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: For this reason and other set out in an opinion filed today with the clerk, we reverse the decision of the Tenth Circuit.

context.speaker: Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
context.text: The judgment of the Court is unanimous.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: But you are not going to suggest that the same tax could be valid or invalid depending on why it was enacted.

context.speaker: Charles A. Rothfeld
context.text: --No, I -- I don't, but I--

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: May I ask one other question before you leave this, which is where Justice Kennedy started?

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Suppose a State says: In our State, we want to tax all oil and gas property, and here's how we do it.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: We assess the value of all oil and gas property, ships and everything else included.

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: I am -- I am saying to you that the State imposes a tax but the State specifically allows Valdez to impose that very tax.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: --That makes matters worse.

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: Valdez imposes that tax as a part of its total taxation package.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Let's -- let's suppose I accept just what Justice Ginsburg said, and said that it's a hopeless morass if we look at all taxes.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Let's look at this tax.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: This tax you call an ad valorem tax on personal property levied by Valdez, and then on page 11 of your brief you say that's not just on ships; it's also on mobile homes, trailers, recreational vehicles, and various types of personal property defined under State law as oil and gas property, motor vehicles, machinery, supplies and maintenance equipment.

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: It is not in any of the cases decided by this Court having to do with the Tonnage Clause, having to do with wharfage fees, pilotage fees, other things having to do with commercial activity in a--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: So we can take as a -- as a given, for the purpose of analyzing the issue, that this tax is either the only tax that's relevant to our analysis or that it's so much higher than all the other taxes, it should be treated as the functional equivalent, as the only tax we have to look at?

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: --I'm saying that it would not make any difference if this was the only tax that the city imposed unless it was a tonnage tax, and the tonnage tax -- this Court has repeatedly--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But the answer to Justice Stevens's question is we can take this case as presenting to us the fact that the ships pay more than other property?

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: --No.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: And you say that doesn't make any difference.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But all you're saying--

context.speaker: Theodore B. Olson
context.text: And--

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --All you're saying is that there are other factors that -- that preclude using tonnage simply as a single crude measure.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But isn't it fair to say that, other things being equal -- the engine capacity, the hull construction, et cetera -- the tonnage is a rough measurement of the value of the ship, for just the reason that Justice Scalia gave?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: It determines the amount of cargo the ship can carry, and what it can charge for it, and that is capitalized into the value of the ship.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Isn't that true?

context.text: Justice Breyer has the opinion of the Court today in two cases.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: The first case is called Polar Tankers versus City of Valdez, Alaska, and that city enacted an ordinance that imposed the personal property tax on the value of large ships that go back and forth to the city.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Polar Tankers owns tanks -- oh that's logical, it owns tankers that transport crude oil from the Alaska Pipeline terminus that ends at Valdez to refineries in other States.

context.text: The State does impose a somewhat similar tax on other oil-related businesses, but in the opinion, we explained why that fact doesn't really matter and doesn't save the tax.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, the questions so far indicate that one of the promises was an implied promise that you will keep the terms of the agreement by lawful behavior.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So that just -- what you say just begs the question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Now, I recognize the government has conceded a breach, and we will probably move on from that point.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But, as Justice Scalia indicates, it puts the case in a very artificial posture, it seems to me.

context.speaker: Lars R. Isaacson
context.text: --It is -- well, it is up to the judge to determine whether or not the defendant gets the acceptance points or not.

context.speaker: Lars R. Isaacson
context.text: The bargain here was not that Mr. Puckett would get the points, but that the government would agree that he was qualified to receive those points.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Where the plea agreement is?

context.speaker: Lars R. Isaacson
context.text: It's page 54a of the Joint Appendix volume 1, paragraphs 8 and 9.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Thank you.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I suppose Justice Ginsburg's point is relevant, though, on the question of prejudice.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: If the judge gets up there and says, I don't care what the government says, I am not going to give anybody a departure when they have committed another crime, then you haven't been prejudiced by the government's breach.

context.speaker: Lars R. Isaacson
context.text: Well -- I believe he has been prejudiced by the government's breach, because once the government violates the plea agreement on the first level, as we know under the prior precedents of this case, it makes the actual plea agreement void.

context.speaker: Lars R. Isaacson
context.text: --We believe that the action of the government, again, rendered the plea agreement itself void, without value, and he would -- Mr. Puckett--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Well, you have to say that.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: But let's assume I don't agree with that.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Let's assume I agree with Justice Alito that his entry into it was voluntary and all that's happened is that one of the commitments on the part of one of the parties has not been complied with.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Why isn't it an adequate remedy for that problem to send it back to a new judge and have the government come before that judge and make the same commitment it was supposed to under the agreement?

context.speaker: Lars R. Isaacson
context.text: --Certainly that is a remedy some circuits have used.

context.speaker: Lars R. Isaacson
context.text: Well, certainly, we -- we'd never suggest--

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: Wow.

context.speaker: Lars R. Isaacson
context.text: --Well, Your Honor, it -- it seems harsh and perhaps it is harsh, but the government has to abide by the contracts they make.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, but I take it -- you never really answered Justice Alito's question.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: I take it that the defendant and his counsel can knowingly recognize that an error is being committed, say nothing, listen to the sentence, and then object later.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That's your position, yes or no?

context.speaker: Lisa H. Schertler
context.text: And in -- and it was unclear that the district court in Santobello even knew what the terms of the agreement were.

context.speaker: Lisa H. Schertler
context.text: This court -- a court in that situation would have been aware -- would have sorted through what the terms of the agreement were.

context.speaker: Lisa H. Schertler
context.text: Now -- and -- and, we don't believe that there is a reason not to apply harmless error review in this context as there is in any other context.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: Excuse me, were you -- Justice Kennedy, were you through?

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I'm sorry, I thought you started a question again.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: The problem I have with the harmless error suggestion that you've made is this.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Is that a possible outcome?

context.speaker: Lisa H. Schertler
